WRITING.TITLE: The Lead Masks Case. Two men were found at a beach in Rio de Janeiro
WRITING.TEXT: [In Brazil in 1966, two young male electronic technicians were found dead in a field, lying on their back with their hands behind their neck in a relaxing position. They were lying on a bed of leaves that seemed to have been hand-trimmed by scissors. They were wearing matching elegant suits and heavy raincoats. Beside them were 2 small sheets of lead cut into the shape of sunglasses, and an empty water bottle. The bartender who was found to have sold them the same bottle of water recalled that they looked nervous and kept checking their watch. This was the last person who saw them alive, although they most likely took a train to their destination.](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lead_Masks_Case)
I want to know, too. :p

That was... deep. It can lead to many different interpretations of what these #8220;real vampires #8221; are, but the title kinda make it self-explanatory. But the best of your poem is its lyricism, the sentimentalism in it. That #8217;s the meaning of poetry, in my opinion: it is a way of put everything off of your chest. And the theme chosen, depression, was the best possible: the way you described the feeling of a depressive accurately (I know this, since I #8217;m one)... Everything on this is just great. Just keep writing, man!

WRITING.TITLE: The Humans
WRITING.TEXT: The human beings (homo sapiens, as they call themselves) are the most intriguing species I, in my entire life, had the opportunity to analyze. If there was a word which could define them perfectly, that word would be #8220;contradiction #8221;. First, let us talk about their planet, which they call #8220;Earth #8221;, or #8220;Terra #8221;, despite it being 70% made of water. It is a rocky planet, the third planet of its planetary system, with atmosphere and weather relatively pleasant, perfect for the life it contains. Earth is an vanishingly small planet (in the very same planetary system, there is another planet hundreds of times bigger). Thus, we could expect the humans to use their resources carefully, once they #8217;re extremely finite. But, as I said before, humans are very intriguing. For the sake of #8220;money #8221;, #8220;progress #8221; and #8220;industry #8221;, words they invented to represent things they invented, they destroy and pollute their small planet, which they call #8220;home #8221;. As a virus, that kills its host. Oh, but even a virus is more harmonic than this species which I was designated to observe! Their wars and spoliations are the vilest of all I #8217;ve seen before; they have no mercy towards their fellow men. Because of that culture of war and excessive battles, their technology grew exponencially; in two thousand years, they evolved in a way no other species in the Universe ever did. Not even ourselves. However, they don #8217;t know how to use that advancement properly: They could be travelling across the galaxy, forcing their place before all other species, but they just can #8217;t unite, not even when it is for the sake of their very planet. The Homo Sapiens #8217;s fate is to self-destruct. Either ending the resources of their planet, or using their massive destruction weapons (that would surprise even Your Excellency) against themselves. Such a shame, since they have so much potential to achieve what they want. But they are warriors by nature, and, without a common enemy, they shall use that hateful instinct against themselves.

WRITING.TITLE: My first OC
WRITING.TEXT: All the times when I #8217;m with no creativity I just think #8216;bout all the times you said #8220;Son, it doesn #8217;t matter how high is the dificulty You can always just write what #8217;s in your head #8221; And all the times when I #8217;m stuck in a line I just think #8216;bout all the times you say us #8220;Son, don #8217;t try to make everything rhyme The beauty of life is the plain and simple chaos #8221; And all the times when I #8217;m about to give in I just think #8216;bout all the times you did it #8220;Don #8217;t think that much, just write everything The worst story you wrote is better than the best you didn #8217;t #8221; And all the times when I have no idea And my imagination just #8217;ve gone home I just sit down and with the words I deal If there #8217;s paper and pen, I #8217;m never alone -OC

John Walkman was on his chair, at his home, just waiting for my arrival. I was just one of the few reporters that interviewed Walkman, or, as he is known in the scientific community: The Photographer of the Dead. That nickname is just because he has no more, no less than 307 pictures with extinct species. From hyacinth macaws to bald eagles, every single animal that he photographed become extinct not so long after the photo was taken. He soon become a legend on the artistic world: everyone would talk to the man who saw 307 extinct species before they went extinct. And, that #8217;s where I came in. A reporter from BBC, to whom was gave the opportunity of interviewing the Photographer of the Dead. John Eleanor Walkman. A living legend. The first thing I noted when I just entered his living room was a little bed table in the corner of the room, with five photos on it. Four of them was of endangered species, but one... One of them was of a little girl. I recognized it from the newspapers. She went missing about two years ago. When I asked him about that, he just said #8220;Yeah, I took a photo of her at request of her mother. I took two photos: one I gave to her, and this one stayed with me, specially after she went missing #8221;. I found that very suspicious, that she went missing the year he took the photo, and in my brain a link was formed between the endangered species and the girl... What if... I shook my head, throwing that idea away. That wasn #8217;t even possible. But I couldn #8217;t help thinking about that, when, after we finished our interview, he came to me, grinning, and said: #8220;Would you mind if I take a photo of you? Just for remembering, one of the few reporters to even come to this house #8221;. I just hope my thoughts are wrong.
Ur mum is so fat she wears a watch on each arm, cuz she occupies two timezones!

WRITING.TEXT: By the time I finish this poem Earth #8217;s been already gone And the blue planet I once called home Now it #8217;s just a memory lost for long It was an experiment, they said No risk, no loss, they also said In the sky now I only see red Red, red, growing red, above my head My Earth died; I saw now in my scope And with it goes my last strain of hope Before it disappear the blue turned taupe From utter destruction, I can #8217;t elope

WRITING.TITLE: [POEM] The Rose of Hiroshima, by brazilian poet Vinicius de Moraes
WRITING.TEXT: Think about the children Speechless, telepatic Think about the girls Blind, inexact Think about the women Changed routes Think about the wounds As warm roses But oh, do not forget The rose, the rose The rose of Hiroshima The hereditary rose The radioactive rose Stupid and invalid The rose with cirrhosis The atomic anti-rose Colorless, scentless Without rose, without anything

WRITING.TEXT: Jesus
Difficult times create strong people. And strong people do not give in.

Okay, this needs some backstory. When I was in High School, I had a very close friend. So close I considered him a brother, since he knew my parents and virtually all my family. He was that kind of guy on High School that knows everyone, talks to everyone and makes friends with everyone. So, we met this girl when we were, like, Freshman or so, and he hated her from the first second he put his eyes on hers. He talked to me everyday about how she was a wanker, and something like that. We finished school, and I went to College on Germany, and ended up losing contact with him. Last month, about fifteen years later, I received an invite to his marriage. With that girl from High School.
It can still be one day
It hurts that you moved on
